Therefore, in the section on realization, there are altogether fifty-five layers of ten grounds.
This is based on one approach.
If one advances to see,
then there are infinitely many layers of ten grounds.
One can contemplate.
Question: In the three vehicles, the grounds are called Joyful, Stainless, etc.
What are the names in the One Vehicle?
Answer: In the common teaching, it is the same as the three vehicles in terms of approach.
If it is the distinct teaching, the names of worlds, oceans, wisdom, etc. are all the names of the ten grounds.
In the perfect teaching, the names of Joyful, etc., and the names of worlds, etc. are all the names of the ten grounds.
That is to say, in the three vehicles, there are only names.
There is no real dharma substance.
In the perfect teaching, the complete dharma substance is taken as the ten grounds.
Moreover, the ten grounds in the three vehicles and initial teaching are vertical positions.
It means gradually progressing from the ten faiths to the ten abodes and finally to the fruition of Buddhahood.
The ten grounds of the mature teaching are the horizontal stages.
It means that they are established within the essence of the one tathÄgatagarbha.
The one vehicle contains both the horizontal and vertical.
It means that the horizontal encompasses the Dharma realm of empty space.
The vertical penetrates the nine and ten time periods.
The ten faiths, ten abodes, and so forth all arise from the ten grounds.
Therefore, Master Zang said:
The ten grounds include the stages before and above the fruition of Buddhahood.
Each assembly in the main part mentions the ocean.
This shows that they all take the ten grounds as the basis.
You should understand that this is the meaning of the abbot.
The Dharma Record says:
Without leaving one ground, it universally includes the merits of all grounds.
This directly clarifies the Dharma of dependent origination.
Therefore, it is said that one includes all.
Question: If it is about dependent origination,
The perfect and unobstructed Dharma
Is sufficient with just one word.
Why must it be said again and again to include everything?
The answer is indeed like this, only saying one ground is enough.
But it is said in accordance with the scriptures.
An ancient record says:
When explaining the passage in the sutra about being in one ground and universally including all grounds,
it is said that from the perspective of the sequence of practices, ultimately reaching the real essence, there are four essentials in summary.
First, because it is the beginning, it can give rise to.
In the end, it is fulfilled, so it is said to include.
Second, although it is the beginning,
it can practice all grounds.
The practices that are practiced are no different, so it is said to include.
However, the practices that are accomplished are only within one's own stage.
The superiority and inferiority between higher and lower are only different in terms of clarity and obscurity.
Third, it is only the beginning, but it includes all the merits of all grounds, so it is called inclusion.
Fourth, it is not called inclusion because of the beginning and end.
It is only because the beginning is precisely the end, so it is called inclusion.
The explanation says:
One says:
The first two are the initial and final teachings, and the latter two are the One Vehicle.
Within the One Vehicle, the first is the dependent origination part and the latter is the fruition part.
One says:
The first is the initial gate, and the latter is the gate.
